We do not want to become a malt snob, do we? Never lose appreciation of a simple but honest classic! Known as 'the honey malt', Dalwhinnie 15 is a great choice for beginners to set out on their whisky journey. Notes of heather, green pears and barley sugar complement the honeyed aroma. After a sweet, rich and full-bodied arrival, spices build up quickly with a mildly dry and bitter edge, but well-measured. The aftertaste is gentle, citric and wood-driven with hints of cinnamon and apple juice. A characterful Highlander which should not be overlooked!RATING: 3.5/5.0 stars ≙ 84 pts → ABOVE AVERAGE

reviews.content: https://whiskylovingpianist.wordpress.com/2020/03/27/malt-n-copper-so-were-back/N: We’ve lot’s on the nose. Light-fresh, light green fruits with a complex mix of subtle yet tight oily/garage/farmy tones. I also pick out a light yeasty meatiness, various fusty honey and sweaty men’s clothes.T: Thin, and at first oily [and sulphury?], before becoming nutty then stretching out with manuka honey.F: A light humming on barley sugar.C: I’ve reviewed and enjoyed this classic malt again [and again] since this tasting [WLP84]. It’s finally time to admit I like Dalwhinnie 15yo.

https://whiskylovingpianist.wordpress.com/2019/12/25/blind-challenge-christmas-2019/Colour: Also gold, slightly richer and murkier than #3 [C]N: More murky than the previous three. Hard to see what that indicates initially.N take 2: After 10 minutes it’s starting to wake up a little so maybe it’s got more age than I’d first anticipated. There certainly appears to be a patient oaky underbelly. It’s all a touch quirky but that dissipates, leading to a more mineral quality. My radar is back to Scotch single malt, Speyside or Highlands, maybe sherry and bourbon cask maturation?T: Ok, we are around the 12-16 age bracket [maybe even 18 if the casks say, are 2nd or 3rd fill]. It speaks of age though it’s the barley spirit that steers, the oak a fine navigator.F: Becomes more murky malty/oaky with only a touch of dunnage action to the tail.C: I’m lost as to what it is. Highland Park perhaps? I think this one will haunt me. Provisionally scores around 85 tops.ROUND 2I piece together a summary of my guess-work:We are in the 12-16 age bracket [maybe even 18 if the casks are 3rd fill]. My guesses ranged from old Highland Park to Springbank with hints of Balvenie in-between. Frankly I’m puzzled by this one. I’m going to kick myself. [85]ROUND 3There’s a 25yo in this bunch and this is certainly displaying plenty of maturity. Again, the nose is quiet yet with a soft whispering leathery story to tell certainly. The palate [if short] tells of age as does the dusty [if not that dunnage-y] finish. Then there are those unmistakable oaky sugars at the tail which tell of age more than the previous signs. Given I’ve mistaken the Glenalba as a NAS and #5 as a 10yo, I’m committed to calling this a soft 25yo. Wrong again! Then this must be a 15yo then. I did say between 12-16 in the beginning!REVEALED: What can I say? I never used to like the Dalwhinnie, yet the last 3 times I’ve had it [the last 2 blind], I’ve enjoyed it.C: I’m pleased i initially had this down at 12-16 years but frustrated I failed to spot the main [and, I want to say recognisable, but in the circumstances] character trait – soft-aged bitter/sour lemon-y malt. Forget the Winter’s Gold that is/was often priced higher than the 15yo.Final score: 84 points

https://whiskylovingpianist.wordpress.com/2018/01/23/rogues-to-riches-part-1/Due to my indecisiveness, I asked the bartender for a dram, blind.N: Similar honeyed nose to the Glenfiddich 21yo WB [coming up], though more bready/porridge-y and a tad more youthful. Less fruits but swizzles more honey.T: Honeyed porridge and a dry aspirin tinge [which thankfully is only a minor distraction].F: Similar finish to the Glenfiddich on honeyed cocoa barley.C: In the same ball park as the Glenfiddich and some Glenmorangie too. This Dalwhinnie has a better consistency and preferred mouthfeel but a far more basic nose and palate. Though I’m no great fan, it is however the best batch of Dalwhinnie 15 I’ve had to date.Scores a B-

N: Almost nothing from the nose as its so cold in the warehouse, even in the height of summer! Warming up to sweet lemon barley spirit, as ever.T: Well, it's Dalwhinnie. You have to give it to them for consistency. It's always the same - neutral, calm cereal notes, with a spirit of fine quality. The casks element always appears tame, safe.F: Clean spirit, spirity.C: I've never understood what the fuss is about with the Dalwhinnie 15, and even today's dram in the distillery isn't going to change my mind eitherScores a D+

N: Sweet, stewed apples, unripe plums, dried papaya<mango, caramel & melting toffee, pear=prune juice and pokey=yeasty, honeyed malt with an old style oak influence. Its sweet and overall rounded, but yet a little wayward, ‘pokey’ being the word.T: Another rugged one [a la Black bottle WB] - starting out with tannic, stewed fruits and a muddled nutty, poly-tar centre leading into a malty dry, oil-slick oak smokiness. A longer journey than expected with the subtle, indiscriminate notes towards the finish offering the most fascination. Adding water can’t get rid of the overall sharpness as it really struggles with itself in the main, only settling in the latter stages.F: Rather a longer finish too with chocolate, jammy notes moving to a nutty, malty conclusion with the malty/waxy/Ovaltine/chicory notes emerging as successors. Theres rather a sublime tequila/G&T conclusion at the death for those willing to wait for the credits, aside from metallic/oily, crisp like industrialness that is.C: The point in-between the palate and finish appears to be this malt’s sweet spot. Otherwise, and despite its qualities its a bit of a struggle - although this 15yo has grown on me somewhat, especially because of its general contentiousness. Batch consistency remains an issue - see Whisky-monitor scores for the Dalwhinne 15yo which span from 1980 up to 2013 [at time of writing, July 2015].Scores a C

N: Highland/Ancnoc like with some Speyside notes. Very fruity, citrus, woody, yeasty - familiar regional nose with some potency. Damp nose but not musty, this is a fresh clean mouldT: Woody, yeasty, sugary, honey arrival becoming more and more malty, citrusy and woody. Some nutmeg/fennel freshness coming out over time and some noticeable salt and vibrancy overall and an Interesting interplay between the sweet and sour but a tad ambiguous.F: Citrus and honey wood lingers. Some bourbon sugars struggling to come throughC: Highland/speysider and not too shabby. A clean, balanced rather safe whisky which whilst having lots going for it, lacks that spark to catch a fire.Scores a C+

reviews.nose: Bright and clear amber glitters in the glass, on the glass wall sticks a syrupy streak from which to solve a variety of long and oily "legs". Creamy roasted flavors and hazelnuts rise, caramel and honey merge together, apples and mandarins are in the air. Minimal hints of smoke dissolve from the sweet and creamy blend of fruit and honey, in addition to the mandarins and oranges are now increasingly pears and creamy toffee. The alcohol is mild and gently integrated, the nose is getting creamier and sweeter ...
reviews.taste: Relatively gentle and mild, the first sip flows over the tongue. Spicy woody tones are immediately mixed with creamy caramel and toffee, forest honey and hints of milk chocolate sparkle briefly before an increasingly bitter aroma sets in the palate. Old whale and hazelnuts stick to the palate, subtle sharpness envelops the tongue while slightly charred logs dissolve smoke and tart wood elements. Still stick the oily streaks and thick "legs" on the glass wall, I get an appetite for the second sip. Slightly watery and thin, the Dalwhinnie drips off the tongue after the second sip, while salty and peppery wood marks burn on the tip of the tongue. Once again, burned wood and toasted cereals, meadow herbs and citrus fruits dissolve from the bitter woody note, tart grapefruit massively stimulates my salivation.
reviews.finish: Peppery and wooden sharpness still sticks between tongue and palate, lightly smoky, roasted hazelnuts and pieces of wood come to mind again. Abrasion of orange peel and grapefruit exude her tart aroma, honey and a subtle hint of smoke create a nice interplay between sweetness and bitter wood aromas. The creamy and slightly smoky nut flavors stay relatively long on the palate, again discreetly tart and spicy wood tones appear in the finish.

Rightly part of the ''Classic Malts Selection''. Extremely gentle, unobtrusive and a pleasure to drink, the 15 ''Dalwhinnie'' is a prime example for me of a well-matured and relaxed single malt with distinct honey aromas, which can be drunk with relish. Simply structured and simply delicious.
reviews.nose: Sugary-sweet white grapes in very light wildflower honey, ripe "Royal Gala" apples and juicy white-fleshed peaches, a few ripe gooseberries and mirabelle plums and even less pear, very flowery and floral, apple blossoms, becomes even sweeter with air, candied oranges and Turkish Honey with almonds, hints of marzipan and vanilla, the clean barley distillate has matured nicely and has a very delicate and delicate texture, some heather in the background combined with a negligible peaty reminder of smoke
reviews.taste: Thin, mild honey, ripe Mirabelle plums and gooseberries bring a nice light fruitiness into play, ripe apples with a mealy, crystalline structure, juicy ''Abate Fetel'' pears, orange marmalade without pieces of peel, the fragile barley that has come to rest through the ripening period is now a little more malty , the light grapes are sucked out and the tannins of the skin let it tingle a little to slow it down, blanched almonds, little marzipan, the mild, bitter-free and somewhat used-looking oak finally has a light note of milk chocolate and vanilla to offer, the minimal peatiness floats together with the floral undertones and a hint of heather in the background
reviews.finish: Very gently ending with a medium length, lots of honey, very light milky coffee with a lightly roasted interlude, turning into black tea with milk and lots of sugar, slightly toasty, unobtrusive oak aromas and vanilla, a hint of hay and heather, some marzipan and blanched almonds, the The sweetness of the Turkish honey along with the floury sugary apple note slowly fades from the scene, leaving a very delicate peaty shadow with a slight aftertaste of Mirabelle plums and overripe gooseberries and yellow kiwis
